ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Intro to chemE topics
Basic introduction to engineering processes, an insight to the engineering way of approaching problems
Great insight into thinking about how to approach chemical engineering problems. Knowledge covered included Energy and Mass Balances, Dimensional Analysis, Scale up/down, Intro to transport.
I received a very good overview of the general concepts that are important to chemical engineering such as kinetics and transport, in a manner that was very easy to digest at a beginner level.
I learned how to apply mathematical models to real world phenomenon using some of the fundamental laws of the universe.

This course taught a superficial introduction into chemical kinetics & reactors design, thermodynamics, and transport phenomena, to give students an overview of the fundamentals of chemical engineering analysis.
I learned about scientific analysis, mass, energy balances, dimensionless variables
Introduction to engineering analysis: primarily mass balances. Problems follow a theme of balancing input1+input2+...=output1+output2+....
Mass and Energy Balances, Non-dimensionalization of variables, Buckingham Pi Theorem, Flux, Fluid Transport

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Loewenberg is the strength because he's one of the kindest professors you'll find at Yale. Weakness was the lack of math teaching to make it more accessible, but I think it just ended up making us more confused.

Strengths: Professor Loewenberg is great, always very willing to help anyone with questions or concerns, and has a vested interest in making sure that everyone is engaged with the material. He is also very accommodating and willing to make changes to the course structure based on feedback. He made sure to have one on one meetings with everyone in the class to get an idea of where we stand with the material and just get to know us better. The psets weren't too long, and were doable if you attended recitation. The recitation system was very helpful, and our TA Rostacia was very dedicated to answering questions, and was always available to guide us if we needed help. 

Weaknesses: The material was sometimes very difficult to understand, and sometimes the lecture notes did not match up with the live lecture, making it slightly confusing.

+Professor Loewenberg and the TF/TAs for the course were amazing. Lots of different opportunities were given to ask questions in lecture, in a Q&A forum, and office hours and the lecture notes provided were great intros and recaps of material. Problem sets were interesting and appropriately challenging.

-Lectures sometimes just 'landed' somewhere which could be confusing to follow. Then again, this is also because there was a lot of supporting material going into the lecture.

Overall, this class was taught very well and was extremely reasonable for a beginner audience, especially non-stem majors. Loewenberg makes the intro to chemical engineering very easy to digest and participate in, and very pleasant.

The level of engagement of the professor as well as the teaching fellows really made this class for me. Some of the concepts that were covered in lecture were a bit difficult to wrap my head around initially, but Professor Loewneberg and the teaching fellows were always there to help the class understand these concepts.

One strength was that it taught the fundamentals of chemical engineering without requiring a foundation in physics, chemistry, and advanced calculus. 

That being said, because it did not require background knowledge, the superficial coverage oftentimes led to a lot of confusion, with us skipping several steps in solving problems, and with a few oversimplifications that led to more confusion. Possibly introducing the fundamentals of solving a differential equation ad coverage of some basic physics concepts would have been helpful in the beginning.

Strengths: Very helpful recitations, professor is very willing to help if you reach out 
Weakness: lack of structure in class, professor jumps to steps which make things a little confusing, sometimes professor solves problem a certain way and then realizes he did it wrong and erases half of what he wrote before which makes things confusing

Strengths: Professor is always seeking for feedback, really cares about students, and great study guides combine knowledge of past homework assignments in preparation of exam. I learned the most in preparing for the exams.
Weaknesses: A little hard to follow, especially with the virtual format. Do not be afraid to ask questions during lecturethe professor expects it.

Various resources were always available to assist with learning the material. Prof. Loewenberg was always willing to listen to feedback and provide assistance. The readings did not correspond well with the in-class lectures, but previous lecture videos and office hours accounted for this setback.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All practices were useful and I recommend that they stick. Lectures improved over the semester as Professor Loewenberg received feedback.

Overall, the somewhat flipped classroom was helpful, especially to rewatch recorded videos at my own pace later or before lectures. Especially since it is hard to focus over zoom, having access to material during non-class times made learning very convenient during COVID.
Some of the prerecorded lectures did not feel very engaging, and many of them were really lengthy.

Virtual lectures were a little more difficult to follow, especially because it was harder to ask questions (in fear of interrupting the flow of lecture).

Breakout rooms with classmates were hit or misssometimes we made little progress, and other times performed extremely well.

Fleshing out and adding more study guides/solutions. I have learned the most from reviewing solutions to the problem sets and study guides

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah definitely take it if you're considering chemE and want to learn a bit more about the major.

It's a course to look forward to if you are a prospective ChemE major. If not, it's still interesting stuff that applies well to other engineering majors, but definitely ChemE focused. I'd review the syllabus and see if you're interested in the topics covered.

Absolutely! For those in the major, this course is a very good overview. For other students interested in chemical engineering but who arent sure or are hesitant about the heavy STEM workload of traditional engineering courses, this is a great way to learn about the field without the strong background.

Take this course if you have any interest in thinking like a chemical engineer. I think this course is very accessible. Although some of the problem sets are a bit long and challenging, the recitations guide you through solving them.
Yes if they are interested in chemical engineering, otherwise this course is a challenging science credit

Absolutely! The class tackles some difficult concepts but workload, grading, etc. are extremely generous, even for non CENG majors.

Be sure to ask questions in lecture. I have learned the most from reviewing solutions to the problem sets and study guides!

Yes, this is a great introductory course for chemical engineering majors. It provides you with fundamental concepts and analytical skills, and it shows that problems can be approached from multiple angles.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also pre-recorded lectures available.
Live virtual proctored exams during non-class times
The course also included live recitations and help sessions.
Live virtual lecture with recorded lecture components
Virtual recitations
N/A
